captions.text:
Happy Halloween playas? This week we
gettin monstorous with Frankenstein by Mary Shelley.

When some playboy named Walton
peeps some hood named Frankenstein in the

North Pole, they begin conversatin and Franky
starts spillin his life story.

As a young’un, Victor Frankenstein
only got two things on his mind: science,

which he calls natural philosophy, and his
cousin Elizabeth’s bangin boo-tay. Mmm!

In college, Victor get so pro at
the science game that he gets drunk off da

power and decide it’s time to try and create
new life.

The result of Victor’s experiement
is a busted-up monster so damn fugly that

Victor wigs out and trucks it straight outta
town.

Later, the monster rolls up on
Victor while he chillin and gives him the
low down on what he been up to.

See, after escapin from Victor’s
stuffy ass crib, the monster posts up at some

village where he start secretly creepin on
one of da families.

The monster learns all sorts of
sh** from these homies- like how to read and

communicate. But none of dat fixes the fact
that he lonely as fu**.

So he decide he gonna try to chill
with these ballas. But as soon as they catch

a glance at his janky- ass mug, they all tweak
out and get the hell outta dodge.

Then the monster say Victor gotta
build him a nappy woman-monster that he gonna

take to the wilds of South America where they
won’t bother nobody.

At first my boy Victor think it’s a
solid idea, but then he starts thinkin “Hold

up! What if they start gettin freaky and make
little monster babies?? AWW HELL NAW!”

Since Victor went back on his word,
the monster gets all torn up and straight

chokes a bitch- Victor’s bride Elizabeth.
So Victor decide he gonna spend the rest of

his days searchin the earth to stomp that
scrub.

But it’s a search Victor don’t get
to finish, cuz he dies chasin his creation.

When the monster finds him layin in chalk,
he realizes that he lonelier than ever, and
all that’s left for him is death.

Say, dawg. Listen up and lemme
school you on this book’s subtitle: “The

Modern Prometheus.”- which servin up some
real talk on the similarities between Victor
and the Titan Prometheus.

In Greek myth, mah homie Promy
straight molded human beings out of some clay.

And in certain stories, Prometheus
was jonesin to give man a lil taste of that

heavenly fire. When he boosted it from the
Gods, Zeus started trippin hard core.

Just like that G-ed up Titan,
Victor jacks a fire from the sky that not

only bringin a plague down on himself, but
errybody in the hood.

But why is everybody havin to ride
this beef? Cuz Victor was chasing knowledge

at the cost of errything else, just like Adam
when he claimin his five-finger discount from
the Tree of knowledge.

And the biblical allusions don’t stop there,
son. As the original

gangsta of the human race, Adam wakes up in
Eden, is given a bangin hunny by his creator,

and is ultimately kicked out of paradise.
But Frankenstein’s monster, as the first

of his kind, wakes up in some broke-ass crib
with body parts slung around, watches his

woman get ripped apart by his creator, and
ain’t never gonna find no paradise. Sucks
to be this fool.

And it’s exactly all this bunk-ass
jive that leads the monster to act like Milton’s

Satan from Paradise Lost- one of the only
books the monster’s ever read. Check it -

But the monster ain’t the only one
slangin dem dark deeds. Naw, son. Victor sippin
the same kool-aid.

Not only do they both waste
eachothers biddy, but they handin out the

same street justice: vengeance. And when its
all said and done, Frankenstein and his monster
ain’t so different.

All them blurry ethical lines point
to the main thematic questions up in here:

“Are we inherently good or evil?” Are
people driven to murder cuz of society’s

sh**? Or is it written from day one that a
playa gonna be a cold-hearted killa? And if
so, who’s to blame? The monster or the creator?

Yo thanks for keepin it OG with yo
boy Sparky. Subscribe and tune in next week. Happy Halloween bitches!

title: Frankenstein - Thug Notes Summary and Analysis

comments.author: TheLyingTruthTeller

comments.text:
+akodox I know all that (I've read the book, FYI). :)
I think it's also interesting, too, that Sparky left out the fact that the 
father of the family the Creature learns from is blind. For those who don't 
know, there's a really touching scene where the Creature goes into the 
house when the father's kids are away and introduces himself as a poor soul 
down on his luck without friends. The blind man pities the Creature and 
wants to help him, since he can't see his face and is therefore unafraid of 
him. But just at that moment, the father's children return and, seeing the 
Creature, they think he's there to do their father harm and they chase him 
away. It's a really effective scene and gives a glimpse of "what if"--what 
if someone had shown the Creature kindness and he had then chosen good over 
evil?
comments.author: TheaterRaven

comments.text:
That part of the book made me even more frustrated at Victor than I already 
was. It's like, "Oh, sure, NOW you're going through all the 'what if' 
scenarios in your head. REALLY? You couldn't have thought this through the 
first time you did this?"
Victor's arrogance and hastiness in the book drive me nuts, especially when 
he starts going, "Oh, woe is me, look at how awful my life is now!" Well, 
gee, Victor, you, a human, with all a human's flaws and with no other 
humans helping you, decided to scientifically create another full-grown 
human. What the fuck did you think was gonna happen?

comments.author: Wilson Tiono

comments.text:
While I wouldn't say that the monster is totally innocent in the matter, I 
feel that if there is anywhere you can lie blame, it's Victor. I wouldn't 
go so far as to blaming him directly for the deaths, (especially that of 
his brother William, which was not mentioned in this video) but he did 
create the monster, making it so hideous that no one would be around him 
long enough to sympathize for him, and then abandoned him completely. Had 
he given the monster sympathy upon his "birth" (or at least made him less 
horrible to look at) he wouldn't feel so utterly ostracized, and therefore 
would likely not have committed the murders.﻿

comments.author: Lisa S

comments.text:
My take on the final question, "Who's to blame? The monster or the 
creator?" - My understanding is that the monster and/or the creator can't 
be accused definitely like the way a math problem can be solved definitely. 
Therefore, I deem this question unanswerable. Why spend time thinking about 
something that is unanswerable? Your thoughts are much appreciated --- 
Maybe just for pleasure, or it might stimulate the brain in a way that 
helps people to think more deeply about things. But then you have to 
realize that you can also learn to think deeply with questions that are 
actually answerable and that can accomplish something useful, like 
scientists seem to do - I tend to think that this is what Einstein and 
Newton did with stuff like gravitation and other things that, you know, 
have been around for all existence - things beyond most of the relatively 
pointless (yet enjoyable) arts and cultures and stuff that humans have 
created, arts and cultures that fade away and are eventually replaced. It's 
the questions of natural occurrences, not human created matters, that 
really interest me personally, because those things are universal and those 
questions are more likely to answer things like why the universe exists or 
why the sky is blue.

Edit: it's now 7 months after I first posted this, and my mindset changed a 
little. I now think that cultures and arts are important maintaining 
people's sanity. Without those, I don't think we would be able to 
communicate as well and live as happily without. But who knows, maybe this 
new mindset is a result of the culture I live in.﻿

comments.text:
In my analysis I thing the book represent the two sides of crime in the 
present culture. You have the so called 'ghetto' crime as represented by 
Frankenstein's monster. For example when the monster killed Liz is was 
brought about by being neglected and not having the basic needs. Then it 
have the 'blue collar' crime, demonstrated by Dr. Frankenstein. So he has 
everything given to him on a silver platter but 'rich and powerful' people 
feel they can do whatever they want so he create a problem, ignores it so 
it worsens and even though he can, refuses to fix it.

The book in my opinion is a struggle between upper and lower class social 
problems...and the real monster to me is  Dr. Frankenstein (the rich) they 
cause all the world's problems.﻿

comments.author: Miranda Pelletier

comments.text:
I'm surprised you didn't touch on the homoerotic subtones present within 
the novel between Victor and Henry, especially given that almost everything 
Victor does is to either avoid women in his life, or (initially) to attempt 
to cut women out of the natural process of giving birth. While it's never 
firmly implied that Victor is gay or asexual, he certainly does seem to 
have an easier time hanging around men than with women to the point where 
he seems almost determined to keep the women in his life away from him.

Otherwise, awesome video.﻿
comments.author: NukethewhalesMO

comments.text: +NukethewhalesMO  you rock!!!!   lol
comments.author: 117MCT

comments.text:
+Lelldorin84 Oversimplification is even worse than over-analysis in terms 
of literature. I'd much rather spend time thinking about something that 
I've read than just taking it at face value and assuming that the author 
had no intention of injecting subtlety into story.

Regardless, Mary Shelley was the daughter of two philosophers; her mother 
being a known feminist as well. Do you really think that she would have 
nothing interesting to say about the sociopolitical issues of her time? Not 
only that, she married yet another philosopher and traveled frequently, 
that in addition to receiving an education not typically given to women 
during her lifetime almost ensures that she was fully capable of 
understanding and writing about complex social issues. At least try to know 
what you're talking about before criticizing others for voicing their 
opinions, you'll appear much less ignorant.
comments.author: NukethewhalesMO

comments.text:
Its a book about a dude who makes a monster out of body parts and it was 
written by a grieving woman who sucked at male characterization.....stop 
over reading into every little action.  The Author was not trying to change 
the world or write this huge commentary about any stupid social studies 
topic.
She had a story in her head, she wrote it down and sold it in hopes that it 
would be entertaining and she would make money. THE END
comments.author: Lelldorin84

comments.text:
Victor's obvious misogyny definitely makes his very tender and intense 
relationship with Henry extra noteworthy and definitely not imaginary. I 
think not mentioning the subtext has more to do with avoiding flames/flame 
wars. Sparky also quickly glosses over the homoerotic subtext in Dorian 
Gray, so... yeah. I suspect it's a tactful omission based on not wanting to 
scare off the kind of people who'll spend 5 or 6 comments attacking a 
viewer for noticing that such a thing even exists in the first place. Much 
of the internet is just too cozy in its heteronormative little bubble to be 
comfortable hearing it.
comments.author: Kat K

comments.text:
When I first read the novel, I did believe there was something strange 
about Victor avoiding the opposite gender. Although, I didn't believe he 
was gay exactly, I thought it was another point Shelley was trying to make. 
That by avoiding the "natural creators" of life, Frankenstein was one of 
them, but then my English professor explained - in painfully thorough 
detail - how Mary was the daughter of Mary Wollstonecraft, author of A 
Vindication of the Rights of Women, and that Victor's avoidance of women 
was his perverse idea that even man could create life. No matter how 
unnatural. That man could dominate all aspects of life, including the most 
essential, conception. Yet, Frankenstein's creation was a failure in the 
sense that the monster came from a laboratory, not a uterus. Thus, 
fortifying the belief that women are equal to men, that they are equal to 
Frankenstein in the sense that they can conceive life better than him. I'm 
not sure if I might be close to being correct, but to be honest there are a 
lot of novels that seem to have homoerotic subtexts. Such as The Last of 
the Mohicans. They seem to, though.
comments.author: Sovereign_Deadly_ Perfect

comments.text:
+Joe Johnson She wrote it while on summer vacation with her husband Percy 
Shelly and their friend Lord Byron.  There has been, for a long time, 
speculation that the two men had a gay relationship; there has never really 
been any real evidence for it though.  But that might be an answer for your 
question.

comments.author: NukethewhalesMO

comments.text:
+NukethewhalesMO  I think a lot of the men in Frankenstein sound and act 
gay as hell, but it seems to me to be more an artifact of the time the 
novel was set in and written in than anything actually homoerotic. But in 
the beginning when Robert is pining on about how attractive and lovely 
Victor is, and how he's a "brother of his heart," I totally had a Community 
moment. Gaaaaaaay.

Also, was it just me, or was this novel boring as hell? You could rip out 
200+ pages and it would be IMPROVED. I was so sick of Victor's pity party, 
his endless sympathy-seeking introspection, and his novels on whatever 
mountains and rivers happened to be at hand that I was glad to see all of 
his relations die.

comments.text:

 Wanting to stay single = homoerotic?

Once again I think you are projecting your confusion or your own sexual

comments.author: Lelldorin84

comments.text:
+Lelldorin84
1. I don't have any sexual man-on-man fantasies... that's something you 
came up with in a weak attempt to invalidate my comments.

2. You really have to be blind to not see where I'm coming from. You don't 
need to agree with it, but seriously... Victor goes out of his way several 
times in the book to avoid women entirely, whether it be to create new life 
without a woman, or to more directly just postpone his marriage to go 
backpacking with Henry while making several comments to his fiance that 
allude to his preference to remain unmarried.

3. Homoerotic =/= homosexual (at least it doesn't HAVE to mean that). When 
I say that there are possible homoerotic themes in Frankenstein, I'm not 
saying that I think there's a whole Brokeback mountain situation going on 
behind the scenes, I'm saying that there are obviously things that are 
going unsaid that COULD mean that Victor is gay, asexual, or has some sort 
of fear of women causing him to remain closer to the men in his life.

Fanfiction and personal fantasy don't even come into it.
comments.author: NukethewhalesMO

comments.text:
+NukethewhalesMO
  I read it, did not see what you're talking about.  You can have

I personally think the book version is a lot better than what the movies 
tried to depict on, especially the Boris Karloff version. I understand that 
he was a legend and I respect his acting. But he made the monster too much 
like a fierce animalistic killing machine. The Monster in the book was 
beastly, but he also had a very curious, enlightened view on the world and 
he learned how to speak and read. But he was a very sad, lonely character 
because all he ever wanted was a friend. A companion to be by he side.﻿

distance himself from his creation.
